repnme.cdata!: Bosnia and Herzegovina - Bridges for peace

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile focuses on bridges
            for peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina. The bridge became a
            symbol of Bosnia and Herzegovina’s tolerance in a region
            known for its ethnic and religious diversity until war
            overwhelmed the former Yugoslavia. Following the conclusion
            of the war, the government tried for several years to
            rebuild the bridge. However, due to lack of financing and
            technical capacity, as well as political and ethnic
            sensitivities, all efforts were unsuccessful. The
            International Development Association (IDA) financed
            cultural heritage pilot project launched in 1999. Because of
            the symbolism inherent in the reconstruction of the Old
            Bridge, the project was meant to promote a climate of
            reconciliation, the main pre-requisite for economic
            revitalization and social cohesion. The re-opening of the
            Old Bridge has contributed to the reconciliation of
            war-divided people living on the banks of the Neretva River.
            In addition to rebuilding the graceful arch of the bridge
            and its towers, the project restored other damaged
            monuments, which helped preserve the character of Mostar’s
            historic cobble-stoned old town. Mostar residents from both
            banks meet again in the old town to attend concerts,
            exhibitions, and other cultural events. Tourism picked up,
            boosting the local economy and triggered new construction,
            the opening of new hotels, restaurants, and pubs, and other
            businesses in Mostar and its surroundings. In July 2005,
            Mostar’s Old Bridge and surrounding old town were registered
            on UNESCO’s list of historic monuments.

This Results Profile focuses on bridges
            for peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina. The bridge became a
            symbol of Bosnia and Herzegovina’s tolerance in a region
            known for its ethnic and religious diversity until war
            overwhelmed the former Yugoslavia. Following the conclusion

repnme.cdata!: Bosnia and Herzegovina - Bridges for peace

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile focuses on bridges
            for peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina. The bridge became a
            symbol of Bosnia and Herzegovina’s tolerance in a region
            known for its ethnic and religious diversity until war
            overwhelmed the former Yugoslavia. Following the conclusion
            of the war, the government tried for several years to
            rebuild the bridge. However, due to lack of financing and
            technical capacity, as well as political and ethnic
            sensitivities, all efforts were unsuccessful. The
            International Development Association (IDA) financed
            cultural heritage pilot project launched in 1999. Because of
            the symbolism inherent in the reconstruction of the Old
            Bridge, the project was meant to promote a climate of
            reconciliation, the main pre-requisite for economic
            revitalization and social cohesion. The re-opening of the
            Old Bridge has contributed to the reconciliation of
            war-divided people living on the banks of the Neretva River.
            In addition to rebuilding the graceful arch of the bridge
            and its towers, the project restored other damaged
            monuments, which helped preserve the character of Mostar’s
            historic cobble-stoned old town. Mostar residents from both
            banks meet again in the old town to attend concerts,
            exhibitions, and other cultural events. Tourism picked up,
            boosting the local economy and triggered new construction,
            the opening of new hotels, restaurants, and pubs, and other
            businesses in Mostar and its surroundings. In July 2005,
            Mostar’s Old Bridge and surrounding old town were registered
            on UNESCO’s list of historic monuments.

repnme.cdata!:
Bosnia and Herzegovina - Cultural Heritage
            Pilot Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the project outcome is rated
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, with only modest
            institutional development impacts. Lessons are conveyed as
            follows. Cultural Heritage preservation can be a viable
            theme for urban physical revitalization, most importantly
            for promoting reconciliation: had the Bridge and Towers not
            been rehabilitated, they would have remained a constant
            reminder of war and divisions among communities. As it is
            now, the re-constructed Bridge is a symbol of re-established
            ties, that better times are ahead, and that the shared
            history will hopefully lead to a better future. However,
            projects in cultural heritage require patience, and the
            involvement of most stakeholders. Particularly, where the
            structure to be renovated is internationally renowned,
            UNESCO participation is essential to ensure technical and
            aesthetic qualities. Given the Bank's limited
            experience in participating in such partnerships, and the
            partner's unfamiliarity with Bank procedures, more
            explicit attention to creating this understanding, might
            have expedited the process. While the impact of the Bridge
            and Towers on the attitudes of the population is
            undisputable, having included smaller components, especially
            public restorations, added a particularly important
            dimension to the project in reaching the communities, and
            providing the citizens with opportunities for benefiting
            immediately from restorations - such as those in the
            neighborhood and monuments components, through the
            renovation of specific smaller community structures and
            public spaces.
